term_definitions.items: Is the presented problem new or this is a follow-up to an existing problem?
The service request concerns a new problem.
The request is associated with an an existing problem.
The identifier of a parent request group.
Carries references back to an original instruction in the context of a non-ACTION archetype.
The id of the composition containing the original instruction.
The archetype path to the original instruction.
The index of the INSTRUCTION archetype in the data instance.
The atCode identifier of the INSTRUCTION/activity holding the actual instruction or order.
Request for a healthcare service to be supplied by another healthcare provider or support agency.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.

In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services in inexact terms, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 month' will be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available.
A short description of the reason for the request.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
For example a referral with the intent of having specialist care take over the care of the patient, or advice on how to proceed with an investigation or treatment.
The requestor's intention as to what they wish to achieve by the request.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available.
Identification of the service requested, by name.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Example: CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
Structured detail defining the service requested.
Narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.

Somtimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some gastroscopies can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking certain medications for a set amount of time.
The earliest date that is acceptable for the service to be started.
The date and time that the service should be started.
Carries references back to an original instruction in the context of a non-ACTION archetype.
The id of the composition containing the original instruction.
The archetype path to the original instruction.
The index of the INSTRUCTION archetype in the data instance.
The atCode identifier of the INSTRUCTION/activity holding the actual instruction or order.
Is the presented problem new or this is a follow-up to an existing problem?
The service request concerns a new problem.
The request is associated with an an existing problem.
The identifier of a parent request group.
Description about the type of procedure.
*Request for a healthcare service to be supplied by another healthcare provider or support agency.(en)
Request for a procedure to be performed.
*The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.(en)
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the procedure. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
*The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.(en)

In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services in inexact terms, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 month' will be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element.
The date and time that the procedure should be performed or completed.
Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available.
A short description of the reason for the request.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
*The requestor's intention as to what they wish to achieve by the request.(en)
The requestor's intention as to what they wish to achieve by the procedure request.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available, eg incomplete laboratory test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
*Identification of the service requested, by name.(en)
Coding of the 'Procedure name' with a coding system is desirable, if available.

*The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.(en)

The status of the request for procedure as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Example: CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
Structured detail defining the service requested.
Narrative description of the procedure requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
*The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.(en)
For example: a procedure may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.
The latest date that is acceptable for the procedure to be completed.
*The earliest date that is acceptable for the service to be started.(en)

Somtimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some gastroscopies can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking certain medications for a set amount of time.
The earliest date that is acceptable for the procedure to be started.
*The date and time that the service should be started.(en)
The date and time that the procedure should be started.
To record details of a laboratory specimen.
Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.
Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.
Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.
The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy, resection.

e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken.
The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.
The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
Dimensions / weight / quantity of sample. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles.
The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy.
The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.
Is the specimen adequate for testing?
Specific issue with a received specimen.
Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.
An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.
An incorrect preservative was used when transporting the specimen.
An insufficient sample was given to undertake measurement.
An error arose when handling the specimen.
The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.
An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.
The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.
The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.
The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.
The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Addtional details related to specific collection methods e.g. needle biopsy.
Carries references back to an original instruction in the context of a non-ACTION archetype.
The id of the composition containing the original instruction.
The archetype path to the original instruction.
The index of the INSTRUCTION archetype in the data instance.
The atCode identifier of the INSTRUCTION/activity holding the actual instruction or order.
Is the presented problem new or this is a follow-up to an existing problem?
The service request concerns a new problem.
The request is associated with an an existing problem.
The identifier of a parent request group.
Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.
Generic request for a laboratory request.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
The preferred date and time by which the service should be performed or completed.
A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
Stated intent of the request by the referrer.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
Local detailed information such as billing requirements.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Structured detail defining the service requested eg CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
A detailed narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
Is the presented problem new or this is a follow-up to an existing problem?
The service request concerns a new problem.
The request is associated with an an existing problem.
The identifier of a parent request group.
Carries references back to an original instruction in the context of a non-ACTION archetype.
The id of the composition containing the original instruction.
The archetype path to the original instruction.
The index of the INSTRUCTION archetype in the data instance.
The atCode identifier of the INSTRUCTION/activity holding the actual instruction or order.
Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.
Generic request for an imaging examination request.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
Stated intent of the request by the referrer.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
Local detailed information such as billing requirements.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.
Identification of the examination requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Structured detail defining the service requested.
A detailed narrative description of the service requested.
A detailed narrative description of the examination requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
Is the presented problem new or this is a follow-up to an existing problem?
The service request concerns a new problem.
The request is associated with an an existing problem.
The identifier of a parent request group.
Carries references back to an original instruction in the context of a non-ACTION archetype.
The id of the composition containing the original instruction.
The archetype path to the original instruction.
The index of the INSTRUCTION archetype in the data instance.
The atCode identifier of the INSTRUCTION/activity holding the actual instruction or order.
Duration for which the referral is valid.
If true, referral is for an indefinite period of time.
A list of people or organisations who are relevant to this referral, including next of kin.
Request for a healthcare service to be supplied by another healthcare provider or support agency.
Request for provision of a specified service by another healthcare provider or organisation.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.

In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services in inexact terms, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 month' will be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available.
A short description of the reason for the request.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
For example a referral with the intent of having specialist care take over the care of the patient, or advice on how to proceed with an investigation or treatment.
The requestor's intention as to what they wish to achieve by the request.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available.
Identification of the service requested, by name.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of person's or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Example: CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
Structured detail defining the service requested.
Narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.

Somtimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some gastroscopies can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking certain medications for a set amount of time.
The earliest date that is acceptable for the service to be started.
The date and time that the service should be started.

template_id.value: PSKY - Patient Request for Service Tracker.v0

term_definitions.items: A general clinical activity carried out for the patient to receive a specified service, advice or care from an expert healthcare provider. Adapted from dracft NEHTA archetype for SKY use.
Service request to healthcare provider is planned.
Appointment for a healthcare provider service has been made.
The healthcare provider has started the service.
All service activities have been completed.
The referral has been ceased before the service has been completed.
The planned service has been postponed.
The planned service has been cancelled prior to commencement.
The service has been suspended without completion.
Coding of the specific service name with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Identification of the clinical service to be/being carried out.
For example: the reason for the cancellation or suspension of the service.
Reason that the activity or care pathway step for the identified service was carried out.
Narrative description about the service, as appropriate for the pathway step.
Type of service to be carried out or being carried out.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for referral. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for referral.
Only for use in association with the 'Service delivered' pathway step. For example: record that this is the 3rd physiotherapy appointment in a planned sequence.
The sequence of the specified clinical service.
The referral has expired before the referral episode has been completed.
Only for use in association with the 'Service scheduled' pathway step.
The date and/or time on which the service is intended to be performed.
Use to capture detailed, structured information about specified aspects of the service.
Additional narrative about the activity or care pathway step not captured in other fields.
Mulitimedia representation of a performed service.
The request has been received by the intended provider.
The request has been assessed by the recipient, possibly resulting in a review of priority or actual service delivered.
The request for service has been re-directed to a different provider.
The patient has arrived and is awaiting delivery of the service.
Document sent from one treating healthcare provider or organisation to another, for the purpose of requesting advice, a service or transfer of care.
For example: Local hospital departmental information or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
